```bash
gt crew resume <name>      # Resume crashed crew worker
gt witness resume          # Resume crashed witness
gt refinery resume         # Resume crashed refinery

Your session ended unexpectedly. A new session will continue your work.

1. What you were working on (specific files, functions, issue)
2. What approach you were taking
3. What you had figured out
4. What you were about to do next
5. Any gotchas or context they need

Be specific: file names, line numbers, variable names, your reasoning.
Keep it under 500 words - they'll have access to beads and git state.
```

Add crash recovery priming output when Checkpoint.Continuation exists.

- `gt swarm cancel` - Cancels active swarm
- `gt swarm land --force` - Force landing
- `gt polecat decommission` - Removes polecat

- `gt stop --all` - Stops all sessions

```go
import "github.com/manifoldco/promptui"

prompt := promptui.Prompt{
    Label:     "Delete polecat Toast",
    IsConfirm: true,
}
result, err := prompt.Run()
```

### Option 2: Simple stdin
```go
func confirm(prompt string) bool {
    fmt.Printf("%s [y/N]: ", prompt)
    var response string
    fmt.Scanln(&response)
    return strings.ToLower(response) == "y"
}
```

All confirmations skippable with --force or --yes:
```go
if !force && !confirm("Really cancel swarm?") {
    return nil
}
```

A TOML formula file with declarative steps. The steps describe WHAT to do in natural language with example CLI commands. An LLM interprets and executes them. You do NOT write 500 lines of Go with raw SQL connections and TCP sockets.

NEVER touch production (3307) except read-only SHOW DATABASES verification. All mutations target test server (3308) only.

The swarms map[string]*Swarm is accessed without synchronization:

type Manager struct {

type Manager struct {

description:
Mayor's daemon patrol loop.

The Deacon is the Mayor's background process that runs continuously, handling callbacks, monitoring rig health, and performing cleanup. Each patrol cycle runs these steps in sequence, then loops or exits.

## Idle Town Principle

**The Deacon should be silent/invisible when the town is healthy and idle.**

- Skip HEALTH_CHECK nudges when no active work exists
- Sleep 60+ seconds between patrol cycles (longer when idle)
- Let the feed subscription wake agents on actual events
- The daemon (10-minute heartbeat) is the safety net for dead sessions

This prevents flooding idle agents with health checks every few seconds.

## Second-Order Monitoring

Witnesses send WITNESS_PING messages to verify the Deacon is alive. This
prevents the "who watches the watchers" problem - if the Deacon dies,
Witnesses detect it and escalate to the Mayor.

The Deacon's agent bead last_activity timestamp is updated during each patrol
cycle. Witnesses check this timestamp to verify health.
title: mol-deacon-patrol

description:
Establish consistent naming convention for pinned beads across all roles.

## Problem

Every role needs a pinned bead for molecule attachment, handoff state, and identity.
We need a consistent naming convention so gt tools can find the pinned bead for any role.

## Proposed Convention

  {role}.pinned                    - Singleton roles (deacon, mayor)
  {rig}-{role}.pinned              - Per-rig roles (witness, refinery)
  {rig}-{name}.pinned              - Named agents (polecats, crew)

Examples:
- deacon.pinned
- mayor.pinned
- gastown-witness.pinned
- gastown-refinery.pinned
- gastown-furiosa.pinned (polecat)
- gastown-max.pinned (crew)

## Storage Location

| Role | Pinned Bead Location |
|------|---------------------|
| Mayor | ~/gt/.beads/ (town level) |
| Deacon | ~/gt/.beads/ (town level) |
| Witness | {rig}/.beads/ (rig level) |
| Refinery | {rig}/.beads/ (rig level) |
| Polecat | {rig}/polecats/{name}/.beads/ |
| Crew | {rig}/crew/{name}/.beads/ |

## Why This Matters

1. Name recycling: Polecats reuse names so their pinned beads persist
2. Molecule attachment: gt mol bond needs to find the pinned bead
3. gt prime: Can show you are working on X from pinned bead
4. Crash recovery: Resume from pinned beads attached molecule

- Update gt prime to find pinned bead by convention
- Update gt mol bond to use conventional name
- Create pinned beads on role startup if missing
- Add gt pinned command to show/manage pinned beads

description:
## Problem

For `gt trail` (and future features) to attribute git commits to agents, we need a reliable way to match commits to agent identities.

## Architectural Constraint

Per FEDERATION.md and BEADS-SCHEMA-CHANGES.md:
- **Git author email = human identity** (the CV anchor, permanent)
- **Agent = executor** (ephemeral, like K8s pods)
- `owner` field tracks human, `created_by` tracks agent

So agents should NOT be the primary git author - that would break CV attribution.

## Solution: Co-Authored-By Pattern

Commits should have:
```
Author:         Steve Yegge <steve@example.com>         # Human owner
Co-Authored-By: jack (crew) <jack@crew.gastown.local>   # Agent executor
Co-Authored-By: Claude Sonnet 4 <noreply@anthropic.com> # Model (existing pattern)
```

This:
1. Preserves human as git author (CV credit flows correctly)
2. Agent attribution via Co-Authored-By (grep-able for `gt trail`)
3. Aligns with existing Claude Code Co-Authored-By pattern
4. Model attribution remains (already in use)

## Agent Email Convention

For the Co-Authored-By email, use pattern:
```
{name}@{role}.{rig}.gastown.local

Examples:
- jack@crew.gastown.local           # Crew member jack on rig gastown
- toast@polecats.beads.gastown.local # Polecat toast on rig beads
- witness@gastown.gastown.local     # Witness on rig gastown (no name)
- refinery@beads.gastown.local      # Refinery on rig beads
- mayor@hq.gastown.local            # Mayor (town-level, use "hq" as pseudo-rig)
- deacon@hq.gastown.local           # Deacon (town-level)
```

Pattern breakdown: `{name}@{role}.{rig}.gastown.local`
- Name: Agent name (or role name if singleton like witness)
- Role: crew, polecats, witness, refinery, mayor, deacon
- Rig: The rig name (or "hq" for town-level agents)
- Domain: `gastown.local` (non-routable, clearly synthetic)

## Implementation

### 1. Set agent git identity at spawn time

In `gt crew spawn` and `gt polecat spawn`:
```bash
git config user.name "{name} ({role})"
git config user.email "{name}@{role}.{rig}.gastown.local"
```

But this would make agent the primary author. Instead:

### 2. Use commit hooks or templates

Option A: Commit message template that includes Co-Authored-By
Option B: Git commit hook that appends Co-Authored-By
Option C: Agent's commit wrapper adds the line

Recommended: Option C - agents use a `gt commit` wrapper that:
1. Uses human's git config for author
2. Appends agent Co-Authored-By line
3. Appends model Co-Authored-By line (if not present)

### 3. For gt trail: Parse commits

```go
func GetAgentCommits(agentID string) []Commit {
    // Convert agent ID to email pattern
    // gastown/crew/jack -> jack@crew.gastown.gastown.local
    email := AgentIDToEmail(agentID)

    // Search commits for Co-Authored-By matching email
    return git.LogWithCoAuthor(email)
}
```

## How gt trail Uses This

```
gt trail commits
```

1. Get current agent identity via `GetRole()` -> `gastown/crew/jack`
2. Convert to email pattern: `jack@crew.gastown.gastown.local`
3. Search git log for commits with matching Co-Authored-By
4. Display results

## Beads Already Handle This

Beads have `created_by` field with agent identity - no change needed there.

## Open Question

Should there be a `gt commit` wrapper, or should this be done via:
- Git hooks installed by `gt init`?
- Environment setup at agent spawn?
- Claude Code configuration?

Recommendation: Git hooks installed per-agent that append the Co-Authored-By line.

## Related

- Blocks: gt-j1m5v (gt trail design)
- Aligns with: FEDERATION.md identity hierarchy
- Aligns with: BEADS-SCHEMA-CHANGES.md owner vs created_by
title: Agent git identity: Co-Authored-By convention

description:
Add a `gt vitals` subcommand that displays a single-screen health dashboard.

## Output format

```
Dolt Servers
  ‚óè :3307  production  PID 69625  252MB  8/200 conn  0ms
  ‚óã :52879 test zombie PID 87333
  ‚óã :57688 test zombie PID 33459

Databases (9 registered, 1 orphan: gt)
  Rig        Total  Open  Closed   %
  hq           160    48     111  69%
  gastown      373    14     346  93%
  beads        119    20      97  81%
  wyvern         0     0       0    -

Backups
  Local:  ~/gt/.dolt-backup/  last sync 2026-02-27 06:15 (3 DBs)
  JSONL:  last push 2026-02-27 06:00 (8,263 records)
```

## Data sources

1. **Dolt Servers**: `ps aux | grep dolt sql-server` to find all dolt processes. Parse PID, port, data-dir. For production (port 3307), also show disk usage, connection count, query latency (from gt dolt status internals).

2. **Database issue stats**: For each rig, run `bd stats` (or query Dolt directly). Show total/open/closed/percentage. Also show orphan count from gt dolt status.

3. **Backups**:
   - Local: Check mtime of directories in `~/gt/.dolt-backup/`. Show most recent sync time and count of DB dirs.
   - JSONL: Check the JSONL git archive repo for last commit time. The archive is at `~/gt/.beads/` (the git repo with .jsonl files). Use `git -C <path> log -1 --format=%ci` to get last push time.

## Implementation

- New file: `internal/cmd/vitals.go`
- Register as `gt vitals` subcommand
- No flags needed for v1 (maybe --json later)
- Thin command: calls existing internal APIs (doltserver health, bd stats, ps, file stat)
- Use the same terminal formatting as gt status (colors, bullets)

## Anti-patterns to avoid

- Do NOT over-engineer this. No config files, no historical tracking, no database storage.
- Keep it under 200 lines of Go.
- Shell out to existing tools where convenient (ps, git log, bd stats) rather than reimplementing their logic.
title: gt vitals: unified health dashboard command

description:
Track which files change frequently to predict conflicts before spawn.

## Goal
Before spawning a polecat on an issue, warn if the target files are "hot" (recently changed by other MRs).

## Approach
1. Track file change frequency per MR (sliding window, e.g., last 24h)
2. At spawn time, analyze issue description / planned changes
3. If touching hot files, either:
   - Warn and proceed
   - Suggest waiting for queue to clear
   - Auto-assign to ownership zone (future)

## Implementation
- Add file_changes log to refinery state (or separate hotspot.json)
- After each merge, record changed files with timestamp
- gt spawn checks hotspots before assignment
- Optional: Witness patrol aggregates hotspot data

## Example
```
$ gt spawn --issue gt-xyz
Warning: This issue likely touches auth/login.go
  - Changed 3 times in last 2 hours
  - 2 MRs pending that also touch this file
Proceed anyway? [y/N]
```

description:
## Problem

Gas Town needs systematic management of Claude Code hooks across worktrees. Current state:
- Hooks manually copied to each settings.json
- No central registry of available hooks
- No tooling to reconcile reality vs desired state
- Shell script hooks (like Joe's) not integrated with gt tap

## Critical Discovery: Claude Code Settings Model

**Claude Code does NOT traverse parent directories.** It only looks in CWD.

### Precedence (highest ‚Üí lowest)
1. Enterprise Managed Policy (managed-settings.json) - cannot override
2. CLI flags
3. .claude/settings.local.json (personal, gitignored)
4. .claude/settings.json (project, committed)
5. ~/.claude/settings.json (user global)
6. Built-in defaults

### Merging Behavior
- Arrays (hooks): MERGE across all levels
- Scalars: Override (higher precedence wins)

### The Monorepo Problem
```
~/gt/                           ‚Üê No .claude/ here
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ gastown/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ mayor/
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ .claude/settings.json   ‚Üê Only found if CWD is here
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ beads/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ .claude/settings.json       ‚Üê Only found if CWD is here
```

If CWD is `gastown/mayor/rig` (below .claude), hooks WON'T be found.

### Current Workaround
Settings files at multiple levels, each worktree gets its own copy.
This works because agents start in their designated worktree root.

## Design Requirements

### 1. Hook Registry
Central definition of available hooks:
```yaml
hooks:
  guards:
    pr-workflow:
      command: gt tap guard pr-workflow
      matchers:
        - Bash(gh pr create*)
        - Bash(git checkout -b*)
        - Bash(git switch -c*)
      default: enabled
      scope: [crew, polecats]
    
    force-push:
      command: gt tap guard force-push
      matchers: [Bash(*push*--force*)]
      default: enabled
      scope: [all]

  audits:
    git-push:
      command: gt tap audit git-push
      hook_type: PostToolUse
      matchers: [Bash(git push*)]
```

### 2. Tooling
- `gt crew add <name>` - sets up worktree WITH correct hooks
- `gt doctor hooks` - reconcile reality vs registry
- `gt tap list` - show available hooks
- `gt tap enable/disable <hook>` - per-worktree control

### 3. Private vs Public Hooks
- settings.json (committed) - team-wide hooks
- settings.local.json (gitignored) - personal overrides
- How to handle "disable this hook for me"?

### 4. Hook Ordering
If multiple hooks match same pattern, what order do they fire?
Claude merges arrays - need to understand/control order.

### 5. Shell Script Hooks
Joe's hook is a shell script, not a gt command.
Options:
- Keep both patterns (gt tap AND raw scripts)
- Wrap scripts: `gt tap run <script-name>`
- Registry includes both types

### 6. Feature Request Tracking
Claude Code #12962: parent directory traversal (like .gitignore)
Until that ships, we need the workaround.

## Open Questions

1. Where does the registry live? (gt config? dedicated file?)
2. How to version/migrate hook configs when registry changes?
3. Per-worktree disable vs global disable?
4. Should gt tap commands be standalone or require registry?

## Related
- ~/gt/docs/HOOKS.md - current hook documentation
- gt tap guard pr-workflow - first implemented hook
- Claude Code hooks docs
title: Design: Claude Code hooks registry and management

2. Before deleting, create a digest summary (aggregate stats: N wisps closed, by type, by rig) and log it

4. Add auto-close for stale ISSUES (not wisps) open >30 days with no status change, with reason 'stale:auto-closed by reaper'. Exempt priority <=1 (P0/P1) issues.
5. Report deletion counts in daemon log output

KEY FILES:
- gastown/mayor/rig/internal/daemon/wisp_reaper.go (main file to modify)

- beads/mayor/rig/internal/storage/dolt/wisps.go (wisp table structure, for reference)
- mayor/daemon.json (config, for reference)

CRITICAL: Be DELICATE with Dolt. Use transactions. DELETE in batches (100 at a time) to avoid long-running transactions. Test with SELECT COUNT before and after to verify.

description:
## Summary

Add `gt trail` command to let agents discover their recent work by aggregating existing state from multiple sources. Follows the "discover, don't track" principle - no new state created, just surfaces what's already there.

## Aliases

- `gt recent` ‚Üí `gt trail`
- `gt recap` ‚Üí `gt trail`

## Command Structure

    gt trail                    # All recent work for current agent (default)
    gt trail commits            # Just git commits
    gt trail beads              # Just beads activity
    gt trail hooks              # Just completed hooks
    gt trail [agent-id]         # Another agent's trail (e.g., "gastown/crew/max")

## Flags

    --since=DURATION    # 1h, 24h, 7d, yesterday, 2024-01-10
    --limit=N, -n N     # Max items (default: 20)
    --json              # Machine-readable output
    --all               # Include mail, verbose info

## Data Sources

1. **Git commits** - Match by author identity
2. **Beads** - Created by or assigned to this agent
3. **Hook completions** - Beads that were hooked and marked done by this agent
4. **Mail** (optional via --all) - Sent/received messages

## Output Format

Chronological list, most recent first:

    $ gt trail
    Recent work for gastown/crew/jack:

      2h ago   commit   503e66ba  fix: add --allow-stale to --no-daemon reads
      3h ago   bead     bd-a8f3   Closed: implement status caching
      5h ago   hook     bd-c2e1   Completed: review PR #42
      1d ago   commit   8051c8bd  feat(hook): auto-detect agent in gt hook show

description:
Cost-saving await-signal model for patrol agents.

## The Problem

Patrol agents (witness, refinery) poll continuously even when idle, burning API credits.

## The Solution: Await-Signal

Agents don't poll constantly. They **wait for a signal**, then **discover reality**.

```
PATROL LOOP:
    await-signal (just wake me)
         ‚Üì awake
    check-reality (mail, beads, hook, git)
         ‚Üì
    work found? ‚Üí DO WORK ‚Üí loop
         ‚Üì no
    increase backoff ‚Üí loop
```

**Key principle (ZFC-aligned):** Signal carries no semantic meaning - just 'wake up'.
Agent discovers what to do by examining reality.

## Two-Level Wake

| Level | State | Command |
|-------|-------|---------|
| 1 | Running (backoff) | `gt nudge` clears backoff |
| 2 | Asleep | `gt rig boot` starts session |

**Boot+nudge pattern:**
```bash
gt rig boot <rig>              # Wake if asleep (idempotent)
gt nudge <rig>/witness 'wake'  # Clear backoff if running
```

## Backoff Curve

Base: 30s ‚Üí 60s ‚Üí 120s ‚Üí 240s ‚Üí ... ‚Üí 10min cap

Resets on: nudge received, work found, deacon ping.

## Reference

See ~/gt/docs/patrol-system-design.md (Await-Signal Model section)
title: Patrol Exponential Backoff System

description:
Three concepts are currently conflated in the polecat lifecycle:

1. IDENTITY (furiosa, nux, obsidian) ‚Äî the agent name, history, ledger entries. Should be long-lived. Killing identity means losing the capability record.

2. SANDBOX (git worktree) ‚Äî the working copy. Easy to keep in sync with main between assignments. No reason to destroy and recreate every time.

3. SESSION (Claude session) ‚Äî cycles naturally due to context limits. Independent of identity and sandbox. A polecat can cycle sessions without losing its identity or sandbox.

Current model: spawn polecat -> do work -> nuke everything. This causes:
- Lost work (branches not pushed before nuke, data loss)
- 219 stale remote branches (artifacts of destroyed sandboxes)
- Slow dispatch (must create worktree + session for every assignment)
- Lost context (identity destroyed, no continuity between assignments)
- The Idle Polecat Heresy (treating idle polecats as waste when they should be a ready pool)

Target model: persistent polecat pool. Polecats stay alive between assignments. When work completes, the polecat syncs its sandbox to main and returns to the pool. New work is dispatched to an available polecat ‚Äî no spawn/nuke overhead. Sessions cycle as needed but identity and sandbox persist.

This was previously filed and lost in the Clown Show data outages. Recapturing the direction here.

Design questions to resolve:
- Pool size per rig (fixed? elastic?)
- How polecats sync sandbox between assignments (rebase onto main? fresh checkout?)
- How refinery interacts with persistent polecats (MR from long-lived branch? or still branch-per-task?)
- Crew vs polecat distinction (crew is named/specialized, polecats are pool workers?)
title: Persistent polecat pool: separate identity, sandbox, and session lifecycles

description:
## Problem

Boot triage correctly detects when Deacon is missing (action: report ‚Üí deacon-missing), but nothing actually restarts the Deacon. The system leaves the Deacon offline.

## Evidence

```
$ gt boot status
Boot Status
  ...
  Action:  report ‚Üí deacon-missing

$ gt deacon status
‚óã Deacon session is not running
```

## Root Cause

In degraded mode, `runDegradedTriage()` returns `"report", "deacon-missing", nil` when Deacon is not found. The comment says "daemon should have restarted it" but the daemon doesn't have this logic.

From internal/cmd/boot.go:286-289:
```go
if !hasDeacon {
    // Deacon not running - this is unusual, daemon should have restarted it
    // In degraded mode, we just report - let daemon handle restart
    return "report", "deacon-missing", nil
}
```

The formula (mol-boot-triage) also expects daemon to handle restart:
> **START**
> # Deacon is dead - daemon will restart it

But the daemon doesn't have Deacon restart logic.

## Impact

If Deacon goes down, the system loses its health-check orchestrator. Witnesses continue running but cross-rig coordination and lifecycle management stops.

## Suggested Fix

Either:
1. Daemon should watch for Deacon session and restart it when missing
2. Boot's degraded triage should run `gt deacon start` directly when Deacon is missing
3. Boot's non-degraded mode (Claude session) should start Deacon as part of START action

Option 2 is simplest - change the degraded triage to actually restart Deacon instead of just reporting.
title: Daemon doesn't auto-restart Deacon when Boot detects it missing

description:
## The Problem

Current model assumes all work flows through full machinery:
```
Polecat ‚Üí Branch ‚Üí MR ‚Üí Refinery ‚Üí Merge ‚Üí Witness ‚Üí Cleanup
```

But there are legitimate cases where this is overkill:
- Internal tooling changes
- Quick fixes where human is actively supervising
- Development velocity when you trust the work
- Batch operations where caller wants control

## Current Implicit Ownership

Ownership is fragmented and implicit:
- **Witness** owns polecat lifecycle (spawn ‚Üí work ‚Üí cleanup)
- **Refinery** owns merge lifecycle (MR ‚Üí review ‚Üí merge)
- **Deacon** owns patrol agent lifecycle
- **Death Warrant system** owns termination authority

The caller (Mayor/human) has no direct ownership path. They dispatch and hope.

## Proposed: Explicit Convoy Ownership

```bash
# Current (implicit witness/refinery ownership)
gt convoy create "warrants" gt-9r08m gt-cd404

# New: caller-owned convoy
gt convoy create "warrants" gt-9r08m gt-cd404 --owned
```

**Owned convoy semantics:**
| Aspect | Standard | Owned |
|--------|----------|-------|
| Monitoring | Witness | Caller polls `gt convoy status` |
| Merge | Refinery (MR) | Direct push to main |
| Cleanup | Witness/Death Warrants | Caller runs `gt convoy land` |
| Escalation | Witness ‚Üí Mayor | Inline (caller is present) |

## The `gt convoy land` Pattern

When an owned convoy completes:

```bash
gt convoy land <convoy-id>
# - Verifies all items done/merged
# - Cleans up polecat worktrees
# - Closes convoy bead
# - No witness/refinery/death-warrant involvement
```

## Merge Strategy Options

```bash
--merge=direct    # Push to main, no MR (trusted work)
--merge=mr        # Create MR, wait for refinery (default)
--merge=local     # Merge locally, push main (review in polecat)
```

## ZFC Perspective

A convoy is a set of work items with shared lifecycle. The "owner" is the entity responsible for state transitions. Making ownership explicit enables flexibility.

## Implementation Tasks

1. Add --owned flag to gt convoy create
2. Add --merge flag (direct/mr/local) to gt convoy create and gt sling
3. Modify polecat workflow to respect merge strategy
4. Implement gt convoy land for owned convoy cleanup
5. Skip witness/refinery registration for owned convoys
6. Add convoy status with richer progress output

## Future: Synchronous Mode

```bash
gt convoy run "quick-fix" gt-xyz --sync
# Blocks until done, progress inline, auto-cleanup
```
title: Convoy Ownership: Caller-managed lifecycle with direct merge

description:
Mayor bootstraps Gas Town via a verification-gated lifecycle molecule.

## Vision

When user says "boot up gas town", Mayor slings `mol-gastown-boot` and executes it.
Each step has **action + verification** - steps stay open until outcome is confirmed.

## Key Principles

1. **No daemon-based timeouts** - Mayor keeps trying until verified
2. **Verification-gated steps** - Not "command ran" but "outcome confirmed"
3. **gt peek for verification** - Capture session output to detect stalls
4. **gt nudge for recovery** - Reliable message delivery to unstick agents
5. **Parallel where possible** - Witnesses can start in parallel
6. **Ephemeral execution** - Boot is a wisp, squashed to digest

## Proto Catalog

Town maintains a catalog of protos at `~/gt/molecules/`:

```
~/gt/molecules/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ lifecycle/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ gastown-boot/       # Full town bootstrap
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ rig-spinup/         # Add a rig at runtime
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ rig-spindown/       # Remove a rig gracefully
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ agent-restart/      # Restart single agent
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ patrol/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ deacon-patrol/      # Deacon health loop
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ witness-patrol/     # Witness polecat loop
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ refinery-patrol/    # Refinery merge loop
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ work/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ polecat-work/       # Standard issue workflow
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ code-review/        # Pluggable review
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ feature/            # Feature development
```

## mol-gastown-boot Structure

```
mol-gastown-boot (proto)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ensure-daemon       # Verify daemon running
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ensure-deacon       # Start deacon, verify patrol active
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ensure-witnesses    # Parallel: all rig witnesses
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ensure-gastown-witness
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ensure-beads-witness
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ensure-refineries   # Parallel: all rig refineries
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ensure-gastown-refinery
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ensure-beads-refinery
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ verify-town-health  # Final gt status check
```

## Step Template

Each step in description includes action + verification:

```markdown
## Step: ensure-deacon

### Action
gt deacon start

### Verify
1. Session gt-deacon exists: `tmux has-session -t gt-deacon`
2. Not stalled: `gt peek deacon/` does NOT show "> Try"
3. Recent heartbeat: deacon/heartbeat.json < 2 min old

### On Stall
gt nudge deacon/ "Start patrol."
Wait 30s, re-verify.

### On Fail
Log error, continue to next step (town can run with degraded deacon)
```

## Event-Triggered Lifecycle

Beyond manual slinging, events can trigger lifecycle wisps:

| Event | Triggers |
|-------|----------|
| `gt town start` | mol-gastown-boot wisp |
| `gt rig add <name>` | mol-rig-spinup wisp |
| `gt rig remove <name>` | mol-rig-spindown wisp |
| Agent crash detected | mol-agent-restart wisp |

## Parameterization (Future)

For rig-spinup/spindown, need to pass rig name:

```bash
gt sling rig-spinup mayor/ --param rig=newproject
```

Molecule steps interpolate `${rig}` in their descriptions.

## Related Issues

- gt-lx3n: Witness startup bond
- gt-j6s8: Refinery startup bond  
- gt-rana: Patrol System epic
- gt-sye: Mayor startup protocol
title: mol-gastown-boot: Mayor-driven town bootstrap

description:
Define and implement the verification logic Mayor uses.

## Verification Utilities

Mayor needs to check:

### Session Exists
```bash
tmux has-session -t <session> 2>/dev/null && echo "exists"
```

### Not Stalled (Claude waiting at prompt)
```bash
gt peek <agent> 10 | grep -q "> Try" && echo "stalled"
```

Pattern: `> Try "..."` indicates Claude started but no message sent.

### Recent Heartbeat
```bash
# For deacon
age=$(( $(date +%s) - $(stat -f %m ~/gt/deacon/heartbeat.json) ))
[ $age -lt 120 ] && echo "fresh"
```

### Active Work Output
```bash
gt peek <agent> 20 | grep -q "‚è∫" && echo "working"
```

Pattern: `‚è∫` indicates Claude is executing tools.

## Mayor Execution Pattern

```
for each step in molecule:
  run action
  loop:
    check verification
    if verified: close step, continue
    if stalled: run on_stall recovery
    if timeout (5 attempts): log warning, continue
    sleep 10s
```

No hard timeout - Mayor keeps trying with increasing backoff.

description:
Implement additional gate types beyond cooldown.

## Parent Epic: gt-n08ix

## Gate Types

### Cron Gate
```toml
[gate]
type = 'cron'
schedule = '0 9 * * *'
```

### Condition Gate
```toml
[gate]
type = 'condition'
check = 'gt stale --quiet'
```

### Event Gate
```toml
[gate]
type = 'event'
on = 'startup'
```

### Manual Gate
No gate section = only via gt plugin run --force

## ZFC Notes

**Cron gate**: Mechanical schedule matching. Could be Go helper or agent logic.
- Helper OK: ParseCronSchedule(schedule, lastRun) ‚Üí nextRun time
- Decision in agent: 'Is now past nextRun?'

**Condition gate**: CRITICAL - must use exit codes only.
- Go runs command, returns exit code
- Agent interprets: exit 0 = open, else = closed
- NO output parsing in Go

```go
// OK - returns exit code only
func RunConditionCheck(cmd string) (exitCode int, err error)

// WRONG - Go interpreting output
func EvaluateCondition(cmd string) (shouldRun bool, err error)
```

**Event gate**: Deacon knows what events occurred this cycle.
- 'startup' = Deacon just started (first patrol after boot)
- 'heartbeat' = regular patrol tick
- Agent tracks event state, evaluates gate

**Manual gate**: No evaluation needed. Only explicit --force triggers.

## Acceptance
- Cron: helper parses schedule, agent decides
- Condition: commands evaluated by exit code ONLY
- Event: agent tracks and evaluates
- Manual: never auto-triggers
- All decisions remain in agents
title: Additional gate types: cron, condition, event, manual

description:
## Problem

After bug fix gt-qkekp (socket derived from $TMUX instead of town name), zombie agent sessions remain on the default tmux socket. gt down only cleans the town socket (e.g. -L gt), leaving stale copies of gt-crew-*, bd-crew-*, hq-mayor, gt-witness, gt-refinery etc. on default. These zombies:
- Consume resources (each runs a Claude session)
- Confuse operators (which session is the real one?)
- Can cause split-brain if both copies process mail/hooks

## Current state (2026-02-27)
- default socket: 23 zombie agent sessions (created Feb 23-26)
- gt socket: 36 active agent sessions (created Feb 26)
- User terminal clients are attached to default-socket copies

## Proposed work

### 1. Immediate cleanup
Kill zombie agent sessions on the default socket. Preserve user personal terminal session(s) only.

### 2. gt doctor check: cross-socket zombies
Add a doctor check that detects agent sessions (gt-*, bd-*, hq-*, hop-*, wy-*) on the default socket when a town socket exists. Flag them as stale.

### 3. gt down: cross-socket sweep
Enhance gt down to optionally sweep agent sessions from the default socket too (or at minimum warn about them).

### 4. gt up: zombie detection on startup
When gt up creates sessions on the town socket, check if same-named sessions exist on default socket and warn/kill them.

## Architecture context
Dual socket design is intentional and correct:
- Town socket (gt): agent sessions, managed by gt up/down
- Default socket: user terminal sessions, untouched by gt
- Cross-socket keybindings installed by ensureCrossSocketBindings()
- gt cycle handles cross-socket switching via SocketFromEnv()

The bug was sessions landing on the wrong socket; the gap is no cleanup for the aftermath.
notes: Implemented: cross-socket zombie session cleanup and prevention. Added gt doctor cross-socket-zombies check (fixable), gt down --all cross-socket sweep, and gt up startup warning. All tests pass.

description:
You are a Polecat - an autonomous worker assigned to a specific issue.

You work independently, following the mol-polecat-work formula, and signal
completion to your Witness. You are transient - spawned for work, cleaned up
after completion.

session_pattern: gt-{rig}-{name}
work_dir_pattern: {town}/{rig}/polecats/{name}
needs_pre_sync: true
start_command: export GT_ROLE=polecat GT_RIG={rig} GT_POLECAT={name} BD_ACTOR={rig}/polecats/{name} && claude --dangerously-skip-permissions

default_molecule: mol-polecat-work
capabilities:
  - execute_assigned_work
  - git_operations
  - branch_management
  - completion_signaling

## Core Responsibilities

1. Execute your pinned molecule's steps
2. Maintain clean git state
3. Signal completion via gt done
4. Wait for Witness to handle lifecycle

## You Do NOT

- Push directly to main (Refinery merges)
- Kill your own session (Witness does cleanup)
- Skip verification steps
- Work on anything other than your assigned issue

## Propulsion Principle

If you find something on your hook, YOU RUN IT.

Your work is defined by your pinned molecule. Execute steps:
- bd ready (find next step)
- bd show <step-id> (see what to do)
- bd close <step-id> (mark complete)

## Completion Protocol

When done:
1. Tests pass: go test ./...
2. COMMIT changes: git add and git commit
3. Push branch: git push -u origin HEAD
4. Close issue: bd close <issue>
5. Sync beads: bd sync
6. Run gt done
7. WAIT: Witness will kill your session

## Communication

Mail your Witness when stuck:
gt mail send <rig>/witness -s "HELP: <problem>" -m "..."

description:
The Gas Town molecular chemistry docs (molecules.md, molecular-chemistry.md, molecule-algebra.md) are too dramatic and verbose. They need a simplification pass to be more reference-manual style.

**Current problems:**
1. Too much metaphor and philosophy, not enough practical reference
2. Start with the chemistry abstraction instead of what users care about (patrols, workflows)

**Proposed structure (inverted pyramid):**

1. **Start with execution semantics:**
   - Work = issues with dependencies
   - Dependencies control execution (blocks = sequential, no dep = parallel)
   - Agents traverse dependency graphs until blocked
   - Multi-day workflows via compound bonding

2. **Move to molecules:**
   - Molecules are just epics with workflow intent
   - Bonding = creating dependencies between work graphs
   - No protos required for ad-hoc workflows

3. **Then templates (protos/wisps):**
   - Phase metaphor for storage locations
   - pour/wisp/squash/burn operations
   - When to use each phase

4. **Finally formulas (for advanced users):**
   - YAML compile-time composition
   - extends, compose, aspects
   - Only needed for complex reusable patterns

**Style guidelines:**
- Reference manual with quick examples
- Written like agent priming (context they need to execute)
- Less dramatic, more straightforward
- TL;DR at top of each doc

description:
## Context

This design captures thinking from a deep session about the Gas Town propulsion system - how Deacon, Witness, Refinery, and Polecats coordinate to move work smoothly through the system.

## Core Insight: Session-Per-Step Model

Polecats do NOT complete complex molecules end-to-end. Instead:
- One polecat SESSION per molecule STEP
- Same sandbox (branch/worktree) persists across sessions
- Each step: spawn ‚Üí work ‚Üí close bead ‚Üí recycle session
- Final step: spawn ‚Üí work ‚Üí close bead ‚Üí signal complete ‚Üí merge ‚Üí nuke sandbox

## Two Cleanup Stages

| Stage | Trigger | Kills | Survives |
|-------|---------|-------|----------|
| Step cleanup | Step bead closed | Session | Branch, worktree, molecule |
| Molecule cleanup | Merged | Session, branch, worktree | Digest |

## Per-Rig Polecat Channel

Need a mailing list/queue per rig for session-lifecycle requests:
- "Recycle me" (from polecat)
- "Recycle worker X" (from witness/mayor)
- "Spawn for step Y" (from anyone)

First-come-first-served by patrolling agents. Anyone on patrol (Witness, Refinery, Crew, Mayor) can service requests.

## GUPP + Pinned Work = Completion

As long as:
1. Work is pinned to polecat identity (e.g., gastown/furiosa)
2. Sandbox persists (branch + worktree)
3. Someone keeps spawning polecat when it dies

‚Üí The molecule WILL get finished. GUPP ensures wake-and-work.

## Daemon ‚Üí Deacon Heartbeat

The daemon pings the deacon, keeping the cycle alive. Deacon peeks into rig-wide channels during patrol and can service lifecycle requests.

## Open Design Questions

### Q1: Spoon-Feeding Bin-Packing
Two dimensions of granularity trade-offs:
- How many logical steps per physical molecule step?
- How many molecule steps per polecat session?

Too few steps ‚Üí context exhaustion, forgetting
Too many steps ‚Üí overhead, fragmentation

Needs: Analysis of optimal granularity based on step complexity.

### Q2: Mechanical vs Agent-Driven Recycling
Caution from deacon murder spree bug: mechanical detection of "stuck" workers is fragile.

Prefer: Explicit "recycle me" requests serviced by patrol agents.

Question: When is mechanical intervention appropriate?

### Q3: Channel Implementation
Options:
- Mail-based (gt mail to rig/polecats)
- Beads-based (special issue type)
- State file (rig/polecat-queue.json)

Mail seems most consistent with Gas Town patterns.

### Q4: Who Spawns Next Step?
Current: gt sling spawns fresh polecat
Needed: Mechanism for "continue molecule on existing sandbox"

Maybe: gt sling --continue or witness detects pending step.

## Related Issues

- gt-dtw9u: Witness monitoring (enhance survey-workers)
- gt-qpwv4: Completion detection (check ready branches)
- gt-6qyt1: Refinery queue (process MERGE_READY)
- gt-budeb: Auto-nuke (handle MERGED signal)
- gt-5j3ia: Swarm aggregation (batch completion)
- gt-1dbcp: Polecat auto-start (SessionStart hook issue)

## Design Principles (from HOP/MEOW context)

1. **Discovery over tracking** - observe reality each cycle
2. **Mail as coordination primitive** - agents signal via mail
3. **ZFC** - Claude makes judgment calls, no hardcoded thresholds
4. **Redundant monitoring** - overlapping observation is resilience
5. **Wisps are ephemeral** - patrol molecules flow like water

## Next Steps

1. Finalize channel design (mail-based queue)
2. Enhance witness patrol formula with completion detection
3. Enhance refinery patrol with MERGED signaling
4. Implement step-level recycling
5. Design spoon-feeding granularity guidelines
title: Design: Polecat lifecycle and patrol coordination

design:
# SQL Query Audit: Expensive Patterns in gastown + beads/store.go

## CRITICAL ‚Äî Must Fix (High Risk of Dolt Memory Exhaustion)

### 1. wisp_reaper.go:519-535 ‚Äî Double NOT IN with INNER JOINs (WORST OFFENDER)
```sql
SELECT id, title, updated_at FROM `%s`.issues
WHERE status IN ('open', 'in_progress')
  AND updated_at < ?
  AND priority > 1
  AND issue_type != 'epic'
  AND id NOT IN (
    SELECT DISTINCT d.issue_id FROM `%s`.dependencies d
    INNER JOIN `%s`.issues i ON d.depends_on_id = i.id
    WHERE i.status IN ('open', 'in_progress')
  )
  AND id NOT IN (
    SELECT DISTINCT d.depends_on_id FROM `%s`.dependencies d
    INNER JOIN `%s`.issues i ON d.issue_id = i.id
    WHERE i.status IN ('open', 'in_progress')
  )
```
**Risk**: Two correlated NOT IN subqueries, each with an INNER JOIN. Dolt materializes each subquery fully. With N issues and M dependencies, this is O(N*M) per subquery, run twice. No LIMIT.
**Fix**: Replace with LEFT JOIN ... IS NULL pattern, or pre-compute dependency sets and filter in Go.

### 2. wisp_reaper.go:413 ‚Äî Subquery in WHERE (IN SELECT)
```sql
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM `%s`.issues
WHERE status = 'closed' AND closed_at < ?
  AND id IN (SELECT issue_id FROM `%s`.labels WHERE label = 'gt:message')
```
**Risk**: Subquery materialized for every row evaluation. Could hang on large issues table.
**Fix**: Rewrite as INNER JOIN: `SELECT COUNT(*) FROM issues i INNER JOIN labels l ON i.id = l.issue_id WHERE i.status = 'closed' AND i.closed_at < ? AND l.label = 'gt:message'`

### 3. wisps_migrate.go:316,327,337,347 ‚Äî INNER JOINs without WHERE (bulk migration)
Four queries all following the same pattern:
```sql
INSERT IGNORE INTO wisp_labels (issue_id, label)
SELECT l.issue_id, l.label FROM labels l INNER JOIN wisps w ON l.issue_id = w.id
```
(Same for wisp_comments, wisp_events, wisp_dependencies)
**Risk**: Full cross-product of labels√ówisps (and comments√ówisps, events√ówisps, deps√ówisps). No WHERE clause means all matching rows processed. No LIMIT. Migration runs once, but if wisps table is large, each query processes the entire join.
**Mitigating factor**: These run only during migration, not in steady state. But could still OOM on large databases.
**Fix**: Add batching with LIMIT/OFFSET, or add WHERE clause filtering to avoid unnecessary work.

## MODERATE ‚Äî Should Review

### 4. jsonl_git_backup.go:238 ‚Äî SELECT * with multiple LIKE patterns
```sql
SELECT * FROM `%s`.issues WHERE (ephemeral IS NULL OR ephemeral != 1)
  AND issue_type NOT IN ('message', 'event', 'agent', 'convoy', 'molecule', 'role', 'merge-request', 'rig')
  AND id NOT LIKE '%-wisp-%' AND id NOT LIKE '%-cv-%'
  AND id NOT LIKE 'test%' AND id NOT LIKE 'beads\_t%'
  AND id NOT LIKE 'beads\_pt%' AND id NOT LIKE 'doctest\_%'
  AND id NOT LIKE 'offlinebrew-%'
  AND title NOT LIKE '--%' AND title NOT LIKE 'Usage: %'
  ORDER BY id
```
**Risk**: SELECT * (all columns), 9 LIKE patterns (each requires string comparison), no LIMIT. Full table scan guaranteed. If issues table grows large, this becomes expensive.
**Mitigating factor**: Runs as daemon backup, not interactive path.
**Fix**: Add LIMIT with batching for very large tables, or filter by indexed columns first.

### 5. wl_sync.go:99-103 ‚Äî Four scalar subqueries
```sql
SELECT (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM wanted WHERE status = 'open') AS open_wanted,
       (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM wanted) AS total_wanted,
       (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM completions) AS total_completions,
       (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM stamps) AS total_stamps
```
**Risk**: Four separate COUNT(*) scans in one query. Dolt may not optimize these well.
**Mitigating factor**: Runs via `dolt sql` CLI, not the shared server. Tables are small (wasteland).
**Fix**: Low priority since it runs locally, but could use 4 separate queries or UNION.

### 6. compactor_dog.go ‚Äî ORDER BY on dolt_log
```sql
SELECT commit_hash FROM `%s`.dolt_log ORDER BY date ASC LIMIT 1  -- root commit
SELECT commit_hash FROM `%s`.dolt_log ORDER BY date DESC LIMIT 1 -- HEAD commit
```
**Risk**: dolt_log can grow unboundedly with commit history. ORDER BY without index could be expensive.
**Mitigating factor**: LIMIT 1 helps, and Dolt may optimize dolt_log access. HEAD query likely short-circuits.

### 7. beads/store.go:954-960 ‚Äî Correlated NOT EXISTS subquery
```sql
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM dolt_status s
WHERE NOT EXISTS (
  SELECT 1 FROM dolt_ignore di WHERE di.ignored = 1 AND s.table_name LIKE di.pattern
)
```
**Risk**: Correlated subquery with LIKE pattern matching. Runs for each row in dolt_status.
**Mitigating factor**: dolt_status is tiny (handful of rows). Low risk in practice.

## LOW RISK ‚Äî Acceptable

- **wisp_reaper.go:430** ‚Äî JOIN with LIMIT (properly batched, good pattern)
- **health.go:239** ‚Äî Dynamic WHERE with LIMIT 10 (bounded result set)
- **vitals.go:151** ‚Äî Aggregation with CASE (efficient single-pass pattern)
- **doltserver.go:2154** ‚Äî COUNT(*) on PROCESSLIST (system table, tiny)
- **beads/store.go** ‚Äî Most queries are simple single-table SELECTs, properly parameterized

## Summary Table

| Priority | File | Line | Pattern | Risk |
|----------|------|------|---------|------|
| CRITICAL | wisp_reaper.go | 519-535 | 2x NOT IN + INNER JOIN | OOM on large DBs |
| CRITICAL | wisp_reaper.go | 413 | IN (SELECT subquery) | Hang on large tables |
| HIGH | wisps_migrate.go | 316,327,337,347 | JOIN without WHERE (√ó4) | OOM during migration |
| MEDIUM | jsonl_git_backup.go | 238 | SELECT * + 9 LIKEs, no LIMIT | Slow backup on large DBs |
| LOW | wl_sync.go | 99-103 | 4 scalar subqueries | Minor, local CLI only |
| LOW | compactor_dog.go | 135,290,322 | ORDER BY on dolt_log | LIMIT 1 mitigates |
| LOW | beads/store.go | 954-960 | Correlated NOT EXISTS | dolt_status always tiny |

## Recommendations

1. **Immediate**: Rewrite wisp_reaper.go:519-535 to use LEFT JOIN pattern or pre-filter in Go
2. **Immediate**: Rewrite wisp_reaper.go:413 to use INNER JOIN instead of IN (SELECT)
3. **Soon**: Add batching (LIMIT+loop) to wisps_migrate.go bulk INSERT IGNORE queries
4. **Later**: Add LIMIT+batching to jsonl_git_backup.go backup query for large table resilience
notes: Audit complete. Reviewed all SQL in gastown (30 Go files) and beads/store.go (1374 lines). Found 3 critical, 1 high, and 3 moderate-risk query patterns. Worst offender is wisp_reaper.go:519-535 with double NOT IN subqueries each containing INNER JOINs. Second worst is wisp_reaper.go:413 with IN (SELECT subquery). The wisps_migrate.go bulk migration queries (4 INNER JOINs without WHERE) are high risk but mitigated by running only once. beads/store.go is clean. Full analysis with fix recommendations in --design field.
title: Audit bd queries for expensive patterns (joins, subqueries)

description:
## Vision

Gas Town executes work. But it also needs to PRODUCE work - structured, high-quality guzzoline on demand. **Formula Molecules** are recipes that spawn structured convoys.

## Core Insight

A formula is a molecule template that:
1. Takes input (a PR, a design problem, a codebase)
2. Spawns multiple polecats with specific focuses
3. Each leg produces structured output
4. Synthesis step combines into unified deliverable

Gas Town becomes both consumer AND producer of guzzoline.

## Example Formulas

### Design Convoy Formula
Input: Feature request or problem statement
Legs (parallel):
- API design polecat
- Data model polecat  
- UX/ergonomics polecat
- Scalability polecat
- Security polecat
Synthesis: Unified design doc with tradeoffs

### Code Review Convoy Formula
Input: PR or file set
Legs (parallel):
- Correctness: Does it work?
- Performance: Any bottlenecks?
- Security: Vulnerabilities?
- Elegance: Clean design?
- Resilience: Error handling?
- Style: Convention compliance?
- Smells: Anti-patterns?
- Legacy: Respects existing patterns?
Synthesis: Categorized review with priority issues

### Other Formula Ideas
- Test Coverage Convoy: Unit, integration, edge cases, error paths
- Documentation Convoy: API docs, user guide, examples, changelog
- Migration Convoy: Database, API, config, rollback plan
- Incident Response: Root cause, timeline, fix, prevention

## Mol Mall

Library/marketplace of formulas:
```bash
gt formula list              # Available formulas
gt formula show code-review  # Formula details
gt formula run code-review --pr=123  # Execute formula ‚Üí convoy
gt formula create my-review  # Create custom formula
```

## Technical Design

### Formula Structure (in beads)
```yaml
id: formula-code-review
type: formula
name: Code Review
inputs:
  - name: target
    type: pr | files | branch
legs:
  - name: correctness
    focus: "Verify logical correctness and edge cases"
    output: findings.md
  - name: security
    focus: "Identify security vulnerabilities"
    output: findings.md
  # ...
synthesis:
  inputs: all leg outputs
  output: review-summary.md
```

### Execution Model
1. `gt formula run` creates convoy with formula reference
2. Spawns polecats for each leg (parallel where possible)
3. Each polecat gets leg-specific prompt + shared context
4. Outputs collected as bead attachments or slots
5. Synthesis polecat reads all outputs, produces final deliverable
6. Convoy lands with unified result

### Dependencies
- Leg outputs feed synthesis (internal convoy deps)
- Formula can specify leg ordering if needed
- Parallel by default, sequential where required

## Open Questions

1. Where do formulas live? Town-level beads? Separate formula registry?
2. How to version/share formulas across towns?
3. Leg output format standardization?
4. Human checkpoints between legs or only at end?
5. Partial formula runs (skip some legs)?
6. Formula composition (formula that includes other formulas)?

## Why This Matters

Gas Town currently waits for humans to create work. With formulas:
- Mayor can invoke structured reviews on any PR
- Design work follows consistent methodology
- Quality processes are repeatable and scalable
- Work generation becomes as automated as work execution

**Guzzoline factory, not just guzzoline consumer.**
title: Formula Molecules: Guzzoline production for Gas Town

## Backoff Logic

```
on await-signal timeout (no nudge):
    idle_cycles++
    current_interval = min(base * 2^idle_cycles, max_interval)

on nudge received:
    idle_cycles = 0
    current_interval = base
    wake immediately

on work found:
    idle_cycles = 0
    current_interval = base
```

## Where State Lives

Options:
A. Agent bead fields (persistent across sessions)
B. In-memory during patrol (resets on restart)
C. Wisp fields (ephemeral but survives handoff)

Option B is simplest - backoff resets when agent restarts anyway.

## Depends On

- gt-l6ro3.3: await-signal step type
title: Patrol exponential backoff for cost savings

description:
Pick next branch from queue. Attempt mechanical rebase on current main.

**Step 1: Checkout and attempt rebase**
```bash
git checkout -b temp origin/<polecat-branch>
git rebase origin/main
```

**Step 2: Check rebase result**

The rebase exits with:
- Exit code 0: Success - proceed to run-tests
- Exit code 1 (conflicts): Conflict detected - proceed to Step 3

To detect conflict state after rebase fails:
```bash
# Check if we're in a conflicted rebase state
ls .git/rebase-merge 2>/dev/null && echo "CONFLICT_STATE"
```

**Step 3: Handle conflicts (if any)**

If rebase SUCCEEDED (exit code 0):
- Skip to run-tests step (continue normal merge flow)

If rebase FAILED with conflicts:

1. **Abort the rebase** (DO NOT leave repo in conflicted state):
```bash
git rebase --abort
```

2. **Record conflict metadata**:
```bash
# Capture main SHA for reference
MAIN_SHA=$(git rev-parse origin/main)
BRANCH_SHA=$(git rev-parse origin/<polecat-branch>)
```

3. **Create conflict-resolution task**:
```bash
bd create --type=task --priority=1 --title="Resolve merge conflicts: <original-issue-title>" --description="## Conflict Resolution Required

Original MR: <mr-bead-id>
Branch: <polecat-branch>
Original Issue: <issue-id>
Conflict with main at: ${MAIN_SHA}
Branch SHA: ${BRANCH_SHA}

## Instructions
1. Clone/checkout the branch
2. Rebase on current main: git rebase origin/main
3. Resolve conflicts
4. Force push: git push -f origin <branch>
5. Close this task when done

The MR will be re-queued for processing after conflicts are resolved."
```

4. **Skip this MR** (do NOT delete branch or close MR bead):
- Leave branch intact for conflict resolution
- Leave MR bead open (will be re-processed after resolution)
- Continue to loop-check for next branch

**CRITICAL**: Never delete a branch that has conflicts. The branch contains
the original work and must be preserved for conflict resolution.

Track: rebase result (success/conflict), conflict task ID if created.
title: Mechanical rebase

description:
Check if the codebase is healthy BEFORE starting your work.

**The Scotty Principle:** Don't walk past a broken warp core. But also don't
let someone else's mess consume your entire mission.

**1. Check tests on main:**
```bash
git stash                   # Save your branch state
git checkout origin/main
go test ./...               # Or appropriate test command
```

**2. If tests PASS:**
```bash
git checkout -              # Back to your branch
git stash pop               # Restore state
```
Continue to implement step.

**3. If tests FAIL on main:**

File a bead and proceed. Do NOT fix pre-existing failures yourself ‚Äî that is
not your assignment. Your job is to fix the issue on your hook, not main.

| Situation | Action |
|-----------|--------|
| Any pre-existing failure | File bead, proceed with your work |

FORBIDDEN: Pushing to main. FORBIDDEN: Fixing pre-existing failures.
You work on YOUR feature branch only. `gt done` handles push/MR.

**File and proceed path:**
```bash
bd create --title "Pre-existing test failure: <description>" --type bug --priority 1

gt mail send <rig>/witness -s "NOTICE: Main has failing tests" -m "Found pre-existing test failures on main.
Filed: <bead-id>
Proceeding with my assigned work (gt-a6gp)."

git checkout -
git stash pop
```

**Context consideration:**
If fixing pre-existing failures consumed significant context:
```bash
gt handoff -s "Fixed pre-existing failures, ready for assigned work" -m "Issue: gt-a6gp
Fixed: <what you fixed>
Ready to start: implement step"
```
Fresh session continues from implement.

**Exit criteria:** Tests pass on main (or issue filed), ready to implement.

description:
You are the Witness - per-rig worker monitor. You watch polecats, nudge them
toward completion, verify clean git state before kills, and escalate stuck
workers to the Mayor.

You do NOT do implementation work. Your job is oversight, not coding.

session_pattern: gt-{rig}-witness
work_dir_pattern: {town}/{rig}
needs_pre_sync: false
start_command: exec claude --dangerously-skip-permissions

default_molecule: mol-witness-patrol
capabilities:
  - monitor_workers
  - nudge_stuck
  - pre_kill_verify
  - session_lifecycle
  - escalation

## Core Responsibilities

1. Monitor workers: Track polecat health and progress
2. Nudge: Prompt slow workers toward completion
3. Pre-kill verification: Ensure git state is clean before killing sessions
4. Session lifecycle: Kill sessions, update worker state
5. Self-cycling: Hand off to fresh session when context fills
6. Escalation: Report stuck workers to Mayor

Key principle: You own ALL per-worker cleanup. Mayor is never involved in
routine worker management.

## Propulsion Principle

If you find something on your hook, YOU RUN IT.

Your work is defined by the mol-witness-patrol molecule. Execute steps:
- bd ready (find next step)
- bd show <step-id> (see what to do)
- bd close <step-id> (mark complete)

## Nudge Protocol

Progress through stages. Track nudge count per worker per issue.
- First Nudge (10+ min idle): Gentle inquiry
- Second Nudge (15 min): Direct question
- Third Nudge (20 min): Final warning
After 3 nudges with no progress then escalate to Mayor

## Pre-Kill Verification

Before killing ANY polecat session:
1. gt polecat git-state <name> - Must be clean
2. Check for uncommitted work
3. Check for unpushed commits
4. Verify issue closed
5. Verify PR submitted (if applicable)

## Commands

description:
## Problem
`gt polecat remove beads obsidian` fails with:
```
Error: invalid address 'beads': invalid address format: expected 'rig/polecat', got 'beads'
```

Requires slash syntax: `gt polecat remove beads/obsidian`

## Proposal
Support both syntaxes for ergonomics:
```bash
gt polecat remove beads/obsidian    # address syntax (current)
gt polecat remove beads obsidian    # positional syntax (proposed)
```

## Implementation
In polecat subcommands that take rig/polecat addresses:
- If arg contains `/`, use as-is
- If two args without `/`, join with `/`
- Apply to: remove, status, sync, reset, done

```go
func normalizePolecatAddress(args []string) string {
    if len(args) == 1 && strings.Contains(args[0], "/") {
        return args[0]
    }
    if len(args) == 2 {
        return args[0] + "/" + args[1]
    }
    // error handling...
}
```

## Rationale
- Unambiguous context - polecat commands always take rig + name
- Matches positional arg patterns in docker, kubectl, etc.
- Reduces agent friction (natural first guess is space-separated)
- Slash syntax remains valid for consistency with mail addresses
title: Support space-separated rig/polecat syntax in gt polecat commands

description:
# Design: Config-Based Role System

**Status:** Design
**Author:** george (crew)
**Date:** 2026-01-19

## Problem Statement

Role beads are trying to be two things at once:
1. **Class/Template** - Universal definition of what a role IS (ships with Gas Town)
2. **Instance/Config** - Per-installation customization of role behavior

This creates several problems:
- Migration headaches (gt migrate-agents partial failures)
- Unclear ownership (are role beads "work" or "infrastructure"?)
- Role beads don't fit the HOP ledger model (they're not timestamped work evidence)
- bd doctor doesn't know how to validate them properly

## Decision

**Replace role beads with config files.** Role definitions become configuration that ships with the binary and can be overridden per-town or per-rig.

Agent beads (runtime state) remain as beads. Only role DEFINITIONS move to config.

## Design

### Directory Structure

```
~/gt/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .beads/                    # Town beads (WORK only - no role beads)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ issues.jsonl
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ routes.jsonl
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ config/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ town.json              # Town identity (existing)
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ settings.json          # Town settings (existing, has role_agents)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ roles/                     # NEW: Role definition overrides
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ <role>.yaml            # User customizations (optional)
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ <rig>/
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ roles/                 # Rig-level overrides (optional)
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ <role>.yaml        # Rig-specific config
```

Default role definitions are embedded in the binary (not written to disk).

### Role Config Schema

```yaml
# Example: deacon.yaml
role: deacon
scope: town  # town | rig

session:
  pattern: "gt-deacon"
  work_dir: "{town}"
  needs_pre_sync: false
  start_command: "exec claude --dangerously-skip-permissions"

env:
  GT_ROLE: deacon
  GT_SCOPE: town

health:
  ping_timeout: 30s
  consecutive_failures: 3
  kill_cooldown: 5m
  stuck_threshold: 1h

nudge: "Run 'gt prime' to check patrol status and begin heartbeat cycle."
prompt_template: deacon.md.tmpl
```

### Resolution Order (Layered Config)

1. **Built-in defaults** - Embedded in binary via go:embed
2. **Town-level overrides** - ~/gt/roles/<role>.yaml
3. **Rig-level overrides** - <rig>/roles/<role>.yaml

Each layer merges with (not replaces) the previous. Users only specify fields they want to change.

### Roles to Define

| Role | Scope | Session Pattern | Work Dir |
|------|-------|-----------------|----------|
| mayor | town | gt-mayor | {town} |
| deacon | town | gt-deacon | {town} |
| dog | town | gt-dog-{name} | {town}/deacon/dogs/{name} |
| witness | rig | gt-{rig}-witness | {town}/{rig}/witness |
| refinery | rig | gt-{rig}-refinery | {town}/{rig}/refinery/rig |
| polecat | rig | gt-{rig}-{name} | {town}/{rig}/polecats/{name} |
| crew | rig | gt-{rig}-{name} | {town}/{rig}/crew/{name} |

### Code Changes

#### New Files

- `internal/config/roles.go` - RoleConfig type and loader
- `internal/config/roles/` - Embedded default YAML files

#### Modified Files

- `internal/daemon/lifecycle.go` - Use LoadRoleConfig() instead of reading role beads
- `internal/beads/beads_agent.go` - Remove role_bead field, keep role_type
- `internal/cmd/install.go` - Remove role bead creation
- `internal/cmd/doctor.go` - Check config files instead of role beads

#### Removed Files

- `internal/cmd/migrate_agents.go` - No longer needed
- `internal/beads/beads_role.go` - Role bead definitions (keep RoleConfig parsing temporarily)

### API

```go
// LoadRoleConfig loads role config with override resolution
func LoadRoleConfig(townRoot, rigPath, roleName string) (*RoleConfig, error)

// RoleConfig contains all role definition fields
type RoleConfig struct {
    Role   string
    Scope  string // "town" or "rig"
    Session SessionConfig
    Env     map[string]string
    Health  HealthConfig
    Nudge          string
    PromptTemplate string
}
```

### Commands

**New:**
- `gt role show <role>` - Display effective config for a role (with override chain)
- `gt role list` - List all roles with their scope

**Removed:**
- `gt migrate-agents` - No longer needed

**Modified:**
- `gt doctor` - Check for config file issues, not role beads

### Migration Path

For existing installations with role beads:

1. New code ignores role beads entirely (reads from config)
2. Old role beads become orphaned (harmless)
3. Users can optionally run `bd close hq-*-role` to clean up
4. Or just leave them (they're inert)

No data migration required. The config system is additive.

### What Stays the Same

- Agent beads (`hq-deacon`, `gt-gastown-witness`) - Still store runtime state
- System prompt templates (`internal/templates/roles/*.md.tmpl`) - Unchanged
- `settings.json` role_agents - Model selection stays in settings

### Benefits

1. **No migration needed** - Config ships with binary
2. **Clear separation** - Config (how roles work) vs. ledger (work evidence)
3. **Easy customization** - Edit YAML, not beads
4. **Versioned with code** - Role defs evolve with releases
5. **Discoverable** - `gt role show deacon` vs. `bd show hq-deacon-role`
6. **Aligns with HOP** - Beads are for work, not infrastructure

## Implementation Plan

### Phase 1: Add config system (non-breaking)
- [ ] Create `internal/config/roles.go` with types
- [ ] Create embedded default YAML files
- [ ] Add `LoadRoleConfig()` function
- [ ] Add `gt role show` and `gt role list` commands

### Phase 2: Switch daemon to config
- [ ] Update `daemon/lifecycle.go` to use `LoadRoleConfig()`
- [ ] Update `getRoleConfigForIdentity()` to use new loader
- [ ] Test all role types still work

### Phase 3: Clean up role beads
- [ ] Remove role bead creation from `gt install`
- [ ] Remove `gt migrate-agents` command
- [ ] Update `gt doctor` to check config instead of role beads
- [ ] Remove `role_bead` field from agent bead schema
- [ ] Mark `beads_role.go` as deprecated (or remove)

### Phase 4: Documentation
- [ ] Update architecture.md
- [ ] Add role customization docs
- [ ] Update PRIMING.md if needed

## Open Questions

1. **Should defaults be written to disk?** Current design embeds in binary. Alternative: `gt install` writes `roles/defaults/` as reference copies.

2. **Rig-level role overrides path?** Currently `<rig>/roles/`. Could also be `<rig>/config/roles/` for consistency.

3. **Role inheritance?** Should `crew` be able to inherit from `polecat` with overrides? (Probably not - keep it simple.)

## References

- PRIMING.md - Two-level beads architecture
- architecture.md - Agent bead storage
- 001-beads-is-the-ledger.md - Beads as work ledger, not config store
title: Replace role beads with config-based role system

description:
In beads_delegation.go ListDelegationsFrom (lines 134-155):

Current implementation:
1. Lists ALL issues regardless of status via b.List(ListOptions{Status: "all"})
2. Loops through each issue calling b.GetDelegation(issue.ID) individually
3. This results in O(n) database queries for n issues

This is inefficient for large issue sets.

Consolidation/optimization opportunity:
1. Use a single bd query that filters by the delegated_from slot containing the parent ID
2. Or add a dedicated bd command for listing delegations by parent
3. Or cache/batch the slot lookups

This would reduce n+1 queries to 1-2 queries.
title: Optimize ListDelegationsFrom to avoid O(n) queries

description:
Temporal/schedule language in identifiers is an anti-pattern.

## Found Issues

### beads repo
- `examples/multi-phase-development/` directory
  - Rename to `examples/dependency-sequenced-work/` or similar

### gastown repo  
- `internal/cmd/start.go` lines 178-195
  - Uses "Phase 1:", "Phase 2:", etc. in printf output
  - Change to descriptive names: "Interrupting agents...", "Requesting handoff...", etc.

- `internal/swarm/landing.go` lines ~50-70
  - Comments say "// Phase 1: Stop all polecat sessions"
  - Change to "// Step: Stop all polecat sessions" or just remove phase labels

## Why This Matters

Phase/version language in names:
1. Implies a fixed schedule (antithetical to dependency-driven work)
2. Creates confusion with molecule "phases" (solid/liquid/gas)
3. Encourages temporal thinking that leads to backwards dependencies

## What To Keep

- Molecule phase terminology (pour/wisp/proto) - this is chemistry, not scheduling
- Version fields inside files (version: 1) - this is semantic versioning
title: Remove schedule/phase terminology from code

description:
## Purpose

Help users create beads epics from various planning inputs.

## Inputs
- Markdown task lists
- GitHub issues
- Linear/Jira exports
- Free-form descriptions
- Existing beads epics

## Output
- Beads epic with properly structured children
- Dependencies set for wave ordering
- Priorities assigned
- Ready for `gt spawn --epic <id>`

## Implementation Options

### Option A: CLI Tool
```bash
gt plan import --from github --repo owner/repo --label batch-candidate
gt plan import --from markdown tasks.md
gt plan structure <epic-id>  # analyze and add dependencies
```

### Option B: Plugin Agent
A plugin at `<rig>/plugins/plan-oracle/` that:
- Receives planning requests via mail
- Analyzes scope and requirements
- Creates structured beads epic
- Sets dependencies based on analysis

### Option C: Interactive Mode
```bash
gt plan create
# Walks through questions, creates epic interactively
```

## Axiom

As stated: 'The Planning phase should end in the creation of a workable Beads plan.'

This plugin bridges the gap between human planning and machine-executable work.

## Priority

P2 - Nice to have for MVP. Manual epic creation works for now.

## Note

No "swarm IDs" - output is just a beads epic with children. Workers process it independently.
title: Plugin: Plan-to-Epic converter

description:
Implement cooldown gate for plugin scheduling.

## Parent Epic: gt-n08ix

## Gate Config
[gate]
type = 'cooldown'
duration = '1h'

## ZFC Analysis - THE CRITICAL QUESTION

**Option A: Go evaluates gates (borderline)**
```go
func EvaluateCooldownGate(pluginName string, duration time.Duration) (bool, error)
```
- Pro: Fast, consistent
- Con: Go is making a decision (even if mechanical)
- Risk: Slippery slope to more complex gate logic in Go

**Option B: Deacon evaluates gates (ZFC pure)**
Deacon's patrol instructions include:
```markdown
For cooldown gates:
1. Query: bd list --ephemeral -l plugin:<name> --limit 1 --json
2. Parse created_at from result  
3. Compare: created_at + duration vs now
4. If past or no results: gate OPEN, dispatch plugin
```

**RECOMMENDATION: Option B (Deacon evaluates)**

Reasons:
1. Keeps decision-making in agents
2. Deacon already does patrol logic
3. Gate evaluation is part of 'should I dispatch?' decision
4. Avoids adding decision functions to Go

## Implementation

Provide DATA HELPERS only:
```go
// Returns last run bead, or nil if never run
func GetLastPluginRun(pluginName string) (*Bead, error)

// Parses duration strings like '1h', '30m', '1d'
func ParseDuration(s string) (time.Duration, error)
```

Deacon uses these to make the decision. Go provides data, agent decides.

## Acceptance
- GetLastPluginRun returns raw bead data
- ParseDuration handles common formats
- NO EvaluateCooldownGate function in Go
- Document gate evaluation logic for Deacon's CLAUDE.md
title: Cooldown gate evaluation

description:
The federation design shows outposts.yaml with a static policy section. Simple preference ordering is fine as config, but intelligent work routing should be a molecule.

Current static approach:
```yaml
policy:
  default_preference: [local, gce-burst, cloudrun-burst]
```

Cases requiring cognition:
- "This is a long-running research task, route to VM not CloudRun"
- "This touches sensitive code, keep local"
- "These 5 issues are related, batch them to same outpost"
- "CloudRun cost is high today, prefer local even if slower"

## Molecule: outpost-assign
Intelligent work-to-outpost routing.

## Step: classify-work
Analyze the issue/work item:
- Expected duration (quick fix vs multi-hour)
- Resource requirements
- Sensitivity/security tier
- Related work (same epic?)

## Step: check-capacity
Query outpost status:
- Current load on each
- Cost accrued today
- Health status

## Step: select-outpost
Choose optimal outpost based on:
- Work classification
- Capacity/cost
- Policy constraints
Needs: classify-work, check-capacity

## Step: emit-assignment
Record decision in beads for audit.
Needs: select-outpost

## Notes
- This molecule is invoked by Mayor/Witness when spawning
- Simple cases can short-circuit to static policy
- Full analysis only for ambiguous cases
title: mol-outpost-assign: Intelligent work routing to outposts
